==Chinese==
{{zh-forms|alt=嬭}}

===Glyph origin===
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|女|乃|ls=psc|c1=s|c2=p}}.

===Etymology===
{{unk.|lang=zh}}.

The old form was {{zh-l|嬭}}. Similar words in the area include {{cog|hmx-pro|*niaʔ²ᴰ||mother}}, {{cog|bo|ཨ་ནེ}}, {{m|bo|ནེ་ནེ||paternal aunt}}, {{cog|km|ញី||female}}. It may be comparable with {{cog|sit-pro|*s-nja-n||breast; milk; suck}}, whence {{cog|ii|ꑍ|tr=nyip||liquid milk}}, {{m|ii|ꀉꆂ|tr=ax nie||breast; milk}}.

It is unknown how the Min forms relate to forms in other dialects. See [http://twblg.dict.edu.tw/holodict_new/iongji/pdf/annesia370pdf.pdf this article] for a discussion of the Min Nan etymon. For similar nasalisations in Min, compare {{zh-l|耳}}.

Colloquial words in different Min dialects show considerable variation – most have an ''n''- initial, but finals and tones differ greatly (although the tone is never a rising tone). Some propose that this is substrate influence, passed on from the maternal Baiyue lineages since the intermarriages between southward-migrating Han Chinese and native non-Han women. Other southern dialects also show remnants of this native word: Hakka [Meixian] ''nɛn<sup>5</sup>'', Cantonese [Guangzhou] ''nin<sup>1</sup>'' ({{zh-l|*姩}} or {{zh-l|*𢆡}}). Compare {{cog|th|นม||breast; breastmilk}}, {{cog|za|noemz||breast; breastmilk}}.

The long-recognised Sino-Tibetan etymon in Chinese is {{och-l|乳}}; see there for more.
